Shi Yuan Gui, whose surname was Li, was a person from Yique.
He was born with extraordinary qualities, being magnanimous and elegant.
As he had karmic affinity from past lives, he vowed to leave the household life. In the second year of Yongchun, he finally attained full ordination and was registered at Xianju Temple.
He studied the Vinaya, diligently and tirelessly, upholding the precepts with unwavering resolve.
Later, he realized the Chan school's great and all-encompassing truth at Shaolin Temple, deeply penetrating the profound and subtle. He then built a hut on Mount Song.
He told his disciple Rensu:
I first lived on the eastern ridge of the temple.
When I die, you must build a stupa for my remains here.
Gui settled in the rocky cliffs.
At that time, someone in a tall hat and wide-sleeved robe, with many attendants, came lightly and slowly, claiming to be visiting the great master.
Gui saw that his appearance was extraordinary, his spirit and discernment unmatched, and he said to him:
Welcome, sir. Why have you come?
He replied:
Do you recognize me, Master?
Gui said:
I see no difference between buddhas and sentient beings. How could I distinguish and recognize them with one eye?
He replied:
I am the mountain spirit here.
I can benefit and harm people's life and death. How can the master look down on me?
Gui said:
If you can give life and death to people, I have never been born. How can you kill me?
View the body as equal to emptiness, view me as equal to you. Can you destroy emptiness and you?
If you can destroy emptiness and destroy you, then I am neither born nor extinguished.
Since you are still unable to do so, how can you give life and death to me?
The mountain spirit bowed twice and said:
I am also more intelligent and upright than other spirits. How could I know that the master has vast wisdom and eloquence?
Please bestow the correct precepts on me, enabling me to transcend the world and assist in its majestic blessings.
Gui said:
Since the spirit begs for the precepts, it is already the precepts.
Why is this?
There are no precepts outside of the precepts. What precepts are there again?
The spirit said:
This principle I have heard is vague, I only seek the teacher's precepts, taking my body as a gate disciple.
Gui declined, but could not refuse, so he immediately set up a seat, burned incense, held a censer, and said:
I entrust you with the five precepts. If you can uphold them, then say 'yes'.
If not, then say 'no'.
The spirit said:
Wash your ears and listen attentively, receive the teachings with an open mind.
Gui said:
Can you not engage in sexual activity?
The spirit said:
I am also married.
He said:
I am not referring to this, I am saying to be without lustful desires.
The spirit said:
Yes.
He said:
Can you not steal?
The spirit said:
What is lacking to me, how could I steal?
He said:
I am not referring to this, I am saying to enjoy blessings through licentiousness, and to bring misfortune through goodness.
The spirit said:
Yes.
He said:
Can you not kill?
The spirit said:
The reins of government are in my hands, how can I not kill?
He said:
I am not referring to this, I mean not to kill those who are innocent or mistaken.
The spirit said:
I can.
He said:
Can you not lie?
The spirit said:
I am originally upright, how can I lie?
He said:
I am not referring to this, I mean not to contradict the heavenly mind before and after.
The spirit said:
I can.
He said:
Can you not be ruined by alcohol?
The spirit said:
I can.
Gui said:
The above are the Buddha's precepts.
He also said:ğŸ”½To uphold them with a mind, but not to be constrained by the mind;
To have a mind for things, but not to have thoughts of the body.

If one can be like this, then even before Heaven and Earth were born, one would not be considered refined; even after Heaven and Earth died, one would not be considered old; even if changing all day, one would not be considered moving; even if completely silent, one would not be considered resting.

If one realizes this, then even if one marries, it is not a wife; even if one enjoys offerings, it is not taking; even if holding power, it is not authority; even if acting, it is not intentional; even if drunk, it is not confused.

If one can be without mind towards the myriad things, then lust will not be considered lust; blessings and misfortunes will not be considered stealing; confusion and doubt will not be considered killing; going against Heaven before and after will not be considered lying; confusion and inversion will not be considered drunkenness. This is called being without mind. Without mind, there are no precepts; without precepts, there is no mind. There are no Buddhas and no sentient beings, no you and no me. Without me and without you, who can keep the precepts?
The spirit said:
My spiritual powers are almost as great as the Buddha's.
Gui said:
Your spiritual powers have ten phrases, five of which you can do and five of which you cannot do.
The Buddha has ten abilities and three limitations.
The spirit suddenly moved his seat and said with respect:
Can I hear about them?
He said:
Can you control the Supreme God, and move the seven stars in the west while traveling east in the heavens?
He said:
I cannot.
He continued:
Can you seize the earth's qi, melt the five sacred mountains, and bind the four seas?
He said:
I cannot.
Gui said:
These are the five limitations.
He continued:
The Buddha can empty all forms and achieve the wisdom of myriad dharmas, but he cannot immediately eliminate predetermined karma.
The Buddha can know the natures of all beings and events from billions of kalpas ago, but he cannot guide those without karmic affinity.
The Buddha can liberate immeasurable sentient beings, but he cannot exhaust the realm of all beings.
These are the three limitations.
Even fixed karma is not solid or lasting. Without conditions, it is also said to be a single period, and the realm of sentient beings originally has no increase or decrease.
There is not a single person who can control any dharma.
Dharmas without a controller are called non-existent.
Non-existence without a controller is called no-mind.
As I understand the Buddha, he also has no spiritual powers, but can only penetrate all dharmas with no-mind.
His functioning manifests mysteriously before sentient beings.
If there is mind and action, functioning will certainly not be universally pervasive.
The mountain spirit said:

I am truly shallow and ignorant, and have not heard the meaning of emptiness. I wish the master would bestow the precepts on me. I will uphold them and practice them. What karmic causes can bind me to the dusty world?
I wish to repay your kindness and do what I can!
Gui said:
I observe the body as having no substance, and observe it as impermanent. The dharma cave is solid. What else do I desire?
The spirit said:

If the master must order me to do something for the world, I will display my little bit of supernatural power to make the five kinds of people who have already given rise to the intention to achieve enlightenment, those who are just beginning to give rise to the intention, those who have not yet given rise to the intention, those who have no faith, and those who will definitely have faith - to see my supernatural traces, to know that there are Buddhas, there are spirits, there are those who can and those who cannot, and there are those who are natural and those who are not natural.
Gui said:
Non-action is it, non-action is it.
The spirit said:
The Buddha also ordered the spirits to protect the Dharma. Could the master betray the Buddha?
Please teach me according to your intention.
Gui had no choice but to say:
The east cliff is a barrier for the temple - it is bare without trees.
There are trees on the northern peak, but they do not provide a screen behind.
Can you move the northern trees to the eastern ridge?
The spirit said:
I have already received the order.
He also said:
I will definitely do it in the dark night with wind and thunder, shaking and moving. I hope the master will not be startled.
He then respectfully bowed and took his leave.
Gui saw him off at the gate and watched him leave. He saw the procession winding like the royal guard.

Moreover, there were azure mists, red clouds, purple fog, and white vapors, crisscrossing and scattering in all directions. The banners, canopies, bells, and pendants, the spears and halberds, soared high into the sky, disappearing into the distance.

That evening, there was indeed a violent storm with roaring thunder, rushing clouds and lightning. The grand halls and magnificent buildings were on the verge of collapse. The monks looked on with trepidation, and the roosters and birds cried wildly, colliding with each other. The creatures were unsettled in their places.
He then said to the monks:

The next morning, the sky cleared, and the pine trees and cypresses on the northern cliff were all moved to the eastern ridge, standing there in neat rows.
Gui said to his disciples:

The Biography of Master Azu of Menxiang in Guozhou during the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Master Azu of Menxiang in Guozhou during the Tang Dynasty. Master Azu was from an unknown place.
His appearance was foolish and dull, and his spirit was dazed. Whenever he spoke, it was always as if he knew beforehand.
Although he had no fixed residence, he often stayed in Menxiang.
Because he followed the dust and tracks of Master Fayun, people came and went in a daze, competing to pay homage and make offerings, which piled up like mountains, but he never looked at them.
If someone had hidden worries or was suffering physically, those who received his guidance would see miraculous and swift results.
At that time, there was a wealthy man named Zhang Zhen in Shaanxi. He had many properties and abundant wealth.
He had no son, and Zhen was always afraid that after his death, his money and silk would have no heir.

Later, a son was born, who was both foolish and dull, with crippled hands and feet, stammering speech, and only a fondness for food, almost no different from ordinary people - his mouth was like a ravine, never satisfied all day.
At the age of seventeen, his parents doted on him and indulged his demands. They invited doctors and sought medicine, traveling thousands of li.

After several decades, the family's wealth was exhausted. Some said to him, The Venerable Master is actually a reincarnation of Baozhi. Why don't you lay out your heart and seek relief for his illness?
So the couple came to Menxiang, kowtowed, wiped away their tears, and asked for his help.

The Venerable Master closed his eyes for a long time and said to Zhen, Your resentment has not yet dissipated, and you will still need several years. I pity your diligent efforts and will remove it for you.
He then ordered them to select a day to hold a vegetarian feast on the river, widely inviting many to witness the liberation together.
He then led his son to the Dharma assembly.
At that time, the crowd knew that Azu was extraordinary, and the onlookers were like a wall.
In a short while, he ordered several strong men to drag his son and throw him into the river, following the rapid current.
Zhen was both sad and surprised, not understanding the reason.
Azu said to Zhen:
I have removed the disaster for you.
After a long while, the son suddenly raised his body above the water surface several dozen steps away from the current, and scolded his parents with his hand raised:
You and I have been enemies since our past lives. Fortunately, I encountered a sage and this dispute was quickly resolved.
If it were not so, I would not have been able to finish my days.
He stood tall and spoke clearly, without any signs of confusion or turbidity.
In an instant, he sank into the water, and nothing more was known about him.
From then on, Azu's fame spread, and those who returned to faith were like those who go to the market.
His methods of guiding and transforming were all of this kind. It was during the Dali and Jianzhong eras.
It is said that in the twelfth year of the Zhenyuan era of Emperor Dezong's reign, he was posthumously titled Great Perfect Chan Master.
Even to this day, in the areas of Shaanxi and Guanzhong, he is still revered.

He enjoyed pounding rice alone, working together with the city people, and providing for the meals in the monastery.

After his death, in the Xiantian era, he manifested in Chang'an. He was not an ordinary person's usual demeanor. The scholars and common people who saw him all bowed in reverence.
Following the footsteps of Master Wan Hui, his subtle manner was also similar, but his appearance of madness surpassed him, and his words were often correct.

Previously, in the kitchen of Guoqing Temple, there were two ascetics called Hanshanzi and Shide, who often worked in the kitchen. After cooking, the two would converse, and many who secretly listened could not understand them.

At that time, Lu Qiu Yin was appointed as the governor of Danqiu, and was about to discuss the carriage - he suffered from severe headaches, and the medical workers had little effect.

Why should you worry?

When you arrive, visit Manjushri.
Luohou said:
Where is this Bodhisattva?

He is the one who cooks and washes dishes in the kitchen of Guoqing Temple.
When he entered the mountain temple, he asked:
Has there ever been a Chan Master Fenggan at this temple?

Where is his courtyard?
Who are Hanshan and Shide?
At that time, the monk Daohui replied:
The old courtyard of Fenggan is behind the Sutra Repository. Now it is empty and only tigers and leopards sometimes come here to roar.

Luohou entered Gan's room and only saw tiger tracks crisscrossing.

He only pounded rice to provide porridge for the monks, and at night he would sing and chant without stopping.

The characters feng and feng appear differently - Wei Shu Shiguan writes feng as in fengjiang, while LÃ¼ Qiu Xu Sanxian writes feng as in fengmin, it is unknown which is correct.

Sometimes he walked slowly in the corridors, sometimes he shouted and insulted people, sometimes he scolded the sky.

At first, Lu Qiu entered the temple to visit Hanshan. The monk Daoxiao said:

This person has a mental illness. He originally lived in a cold cliff. He likes to compose poems and verses. His words are not always consistent. Sometimes they are good, sometimes bad. In the end, they cannot be understood.

The monks of the temple were surprised to see the prefect bowing to him, saying:

The two of them linked arms and laughed as they left the temple.
Lu Qiu went to Hanshan's cold cliff again to pay his respects and sent him clothes and medicine. He then shouted and said:
They are robbing me! They are robbing me!
He then shrank his body and entered the seam of a rock crevice, and said again:
Report to all of you, each of you exert yourselves.
The seam of the rock crevice disappeared and merged, leaving no trace.

He then ordered monk Seng Daqiu to search for his remaining belongings. Only the verses written on leaves in the forest and those copied on the walls of village houses, totaling over two hundred pieces, were now compiled into a collection, which many people recited.
Later, Chan Master Caoshan Jing annotated it and called it Verses in Response to Hanshanzi - because he had no clan name, the people of Yue only called him Hanshanzi.
There are lines such as What is there in the courtyard? White clouds embrace the secluded stone, which are elegant and clear.
Below the cliff, there is a stone standing tall, called Secluded Stone.

Shide was a Chan master who once went on a mountain walk to the side of a road in Cheng. He heard a baby crying and went to look for it. He saw a child about two or three years old. At first, he thought it was a child left by a cowherd.
He inquired about the situation, and the child said:
There is no home. I was abandoned here.
Fenggan took him to Guoqing Temple and entrusted him to a monk in charge of meals.
If someone came to claim him, he would definitely return him.
Later, a monk named Lingyi accepted him and let him take care of the incense and lamps in the dining hall.
Suddenly one day, he saw Shide sitting on the seat, eating from the same plate as the Buddha statue.
He also called Jiao Chenru, saying, You are a small fruit arhat.
He acted as if no one else was there, holding his chopsticks and laughing loudly. The monks then drove him away.

Lingyi consulted with the venerable elders and removed him from his position in the hall. He was then assigned to the kitchen to wash dishes. After washing the dishes, he would filter the leftover food and store it in a tube.
When Hanshan came, he would carry it away.
He also took care of the temple's guardian deity shrine, and every day he would take food from the monks' kitchen, which was taken by crows and birds and left in disarray.
Shide would then hit the clay statue with his staff three or two times and scold it, saying:
You can't even protect your own food, how can you protect the temple?
That evening the deity appeared in a dream to the monks of the entire temple, saying:
Shide hit me.
The next day the monks told their dreams, which matched, and the entire temple was in an uproar, only then realizing he was no ordinary person.
At that time they reported it to the local government, and the county decree came down, saying:
Wise gentlemen hide in seclusion, and bodhisattvas manifest in response. It is fitting to honor them.
Shide was called a wise gentleman.
He also herded cows at the temple's farm, singing and calling out to the heavens.
When the temple monks were holding the poá¹£adha ceremony, Shide drove the cows to the assembly hall in front of the monks, leaned against the door, clapped his hands and laughed loudly, saying:
You aimless ones gather together.
At that time the chief monk who upheld the precepts scolded him, saying:
Why are the wind people disturbing the precepts?
Shih-te said:
I am not herding cows. These cows are mostly the monks in charge of affairs in this temple.

Shih-te each called out the posthumous name of the deceased monk, and the cows each responded and passed by. The entire assembly was astonished and all thought of reforming their past and cultivating the future, moved by the Bodhisattva's manifestation to deliver them.
At that time, Daoqi compiled the writings of Hanshan on the wall of the local deity temple of the monastery, and saw the verses of Shih-te, appended to the Hanshan Collection.
It is said:

According to Fenggan's travels in the capital during the Tianxian period, he knew that Luqiu, Hanshan, and Shih-te were all people of the time of Emperor Ruizong. How can it be that Xuan Shi's Biographies of Eminent Monks includes Luqiu, a military official, who was a person of the early Tang?
Luqiu's preface and record of the three people does not mention the year, causing people to be confused.
Again, he was given purple, which is a literary title.
Thus, there were two people with the same name of Luqiu.

Moreover, when Great Eminent of Dahong met Hanshan at the court of Emperor Xizong, he pointed to his Leitan, and again encountered Shide at Guoqing, knowing that the three of them still existed during the end of the Tang Dynasty.

Is it because their lifespan was extremely long?

Tang Dynasty, Chengdu, Jingzhong Temple, Master of No-characteristics, also known as Zhixun Chan Master, was a person from Silla, the third son of the king of that country, born on a certain day of a certain month in his home country, and ordained at Qunnan Temple.
In the 16th year of Kaiyuan, he crossed the East Sea and arrived in China, reaching the capital.
Xuanzong summoned him and he was affiliated with Chan Ding Temple.
Later, he entered Shu and Zizhong to pay respects to Chan Master Zhizhen.
There was an unusual person named Chu Ji, whom Empress Wu Zetian had once summoned to the palace and bestowed a nine-strip hemp robe. He could foresee things and was never wrong.
Before Xiang had arrived, Ji said:
An outsider is coming, you will see him soon.
You should sweep and wait for him.
The next day, Xiang indeed arrived. Master Ji gave him the name Wuxiang.

At midnight, he gave him the hemp robe. In this way, he entered a deep valley and sat in meditation under a cliff. Two black calves rubbed their horns and rolled under his seat, getting very close to him. The cold was like ice, touching his belly. Xiang remained completely unmoved.
Every time he entered concentration, it was often for five days.
Suddenly, there was heavy snow, and two fierce beasts came. He washed himself, lay naked in front of them, and wished to offer his body as food for them.
The two beasts sniffed from head to toe and left.
Often at night, he sat under the bed, stroking the tiger's whiskers.
After staying in the mountains for some time, his clothes were torn and his hair grew long. Hunters suspected him to be a strange beast and were about to shoot him, but stopped.
Later, he entered the city and stayed in the cemetery during the day, sitting under a tree at night.
He truly practiced the austere practices.
People gradually respected him, and a monastery was built for him in front of the chaotic graves.
The Prefect Zhang Qiujian came to pay homage to him.
When Emperor Xuanzong was forced to flee to Shu, he invited Xiang to enter the inner palace.

When he was being honored and worshipped, the County Magistrate of Chengdu, Yang Yi, suspected him of being a sorcerer, so he issued a warrant to arrest him, ordering more than twenty disciples to drag him.
When the disciples approached his body, they all trembled in fear, losing their minds.
After a while, a great wind suddenly arose, sand and gravel flew up, and went straight into the hall, blowing the curtains and rolling up the screens.
Yang Yi kowtowed and prostrated himself, panting and not daring to speak.
After the repentance was finished, the wind stopped, and he respectfully sent it back to its original place.
From this, he further encouraged his patrons to build Jingzhong, Dacisi, Putan, and Ningguo temples.
The number of monasteries and pagodas in the suburbs cannot be counted.
He first lived in the original courtyard of Jingzhong, and later it was called Songxi.
When Xiang arrived in Chengdu, a strong man suddenly claimed to have cut firewood to provide for the monks' kitchen.

Xiang's younger brother had newly become the king of his country. Fearing that he would return, his position was in danger. He was about to send an assassin to kill him. Xiang had already secretly known this.
Suddenly, the virtuous one who had been providing firewood for a day came and said to him:
There are guests tonight.ğŸ”½He said:
Indeed.
He also said:
Do not harm the Buddha's disciples.

At night, the firewood carrier brought a knife and sat on a mat beside the meditation seat. After a while, he felt something falling from the wall and suddenly jumped up, slashing with his knife, and the giant barbarian's head and body were separated on the ground.
There was originally a large pit at the back gate, so he dragged the body over and buried it, and then covered the tracks with soil and left.
At dawn, the abbot ordered the firewood carrier to be summoned and thanked him, but he was already gone.
He once pointed to the cypress tree in front of the pagoda and said:
When this tree is as tall as the pagoda, the temple will be destroyed.
When the Huichang persecution occurred, the tree was exactly as tall as the pagoda.

He also said that there were two small ponds in front of the temple, one for soup and the other for rice. When there were few offerings during vegetarian feasts, he ordered them to be dredged, and offerings would come.
His spiritual manifestations were of this kind.
On the nineteenth day of the fifth month in the first year of the Zhide era, he passed away without illness, at the age of seventy-seven.
When he was about to die, someone asked him:
Who can succeed to the abbacy?
Then he took up his brush and wrote a hundred characters, all of them obscure and unintelligible, yet harmonious and rhythmical.
The events recorded were eighty or ninety years later, and they were verified without error.
Previously, during the reign of Emperor Wuzong, when Buddhism was suppressed, only one temple, Dacien, was left in Chengdu, and the monks of Jingzhong were also ordered to disband.
The large bell of their temple was moved to Dacien.
When Emperor Xuanzong revived Buddhism, the bell was returned to Jingzhong. Because the bell was large and across the river, it was calculated that it would take two days to arrive.
The next day, they were about to hold a vegetarian feast and go to welcome it at noon, but it had already arrived by noon. The force pushing and pulling it was as if it were flying.
Everyone marveled at its divine speed, which could not have been achieved by human power.

The relics of the image, the divided clay, and the true form, on that day all sweated. The monk Li Seng wiped it with a towel, and those who touched it with their fingers found the sweat to be somewhat salty. It was then known that the spiritual power of the image had pulled the bell by itself.
The changes were like this, how great!
Later it was called the Stupa of the Great Master of the Eastern Sea.

In the third year of Ganyuan, Han Wei, the Prefect of Zizhou, composed a stele inscription. In the Kai Cheng era, Li Shangyin wrote the Stele of the Hall of Four Testimonies in Zizhou, promoting the image as one of the testimonies.
The Biography of Shi Huaishen of Xiling Tathagata Temple in Yangzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Huaishen lived in Guangling, and there were no miracles.
In the third year of Huichang, the year of Guihai, Emperor Wuzong, due to Zhao Guizhen, destroyed Buddhism and was about to obliterate the teachings.

Looking back, he saw a pagoda to the east. This was the pagoda of Xiling Temple in Huainan.

On the third level of the pagoda, he saw Xin leaning on the railing, conversing with Yin. He said:

In a few days, Yin returned to Yangzhou and went to visit Xin.
Xin said:

Yin immediately understood and awakened.
Later, in a few days, a heavenly fire burned the pagoda to the ground. White rain poured down, and a nearby grass hut was not damaged at all.
Judging from this, it is not wrong for the people of the East Sea to say they saw Yongning Pagoda.
The author says:
When the pagoda burned, they all said it went to the East Sea. Could the sea really accept the burning ashes?
The author replies:
The five elements are also the nature of the seven great elements. Can they not pervade the Dharma realm?
If they follow, they give rise to each other; if they oppose, they harm each other.
Although opposition and following occur at different times, they share the same scope as the dharma realm, and one can only know that there is 'consciousness' through realization.
Moreover, celestial beings, immortals, and ghosts oppose humans:

The superior gods have palaces of fixed fruits, the immortals attach to objects and transform, and the ghosts and spirits enjoy the food and energy - the class of substantial obstructions, when transformed by fire, can obtain enjoyment.
In general, the majestic and beautiful pagodas are often taken by ghosts and spirits.
The Duke of Hai and Chuan are also not human. For example, the Tianzhu Pavilion in Chen was burned by heavenly fire, and people by the East Sea sometimes saw the shadow of the pavilion.

Also, recently, when the Ma clan ruled Hunan, in the last years, the Tianze Pavilion was burned by heavenly fire. The prefect of Langzhou heard someone in the sky shouting Avoid! The Tianze Pavilion is coming!
In the clouds, it was as if millions of people were carrying heavy objects, and for many days, it was only the fire in the Tianze Pavilion in Tan Prefecture.
If one has faith and sees Liu Yin's dream, faith is also an immeasurable monk.

Previously, there were seven tile kilns south of the county town. On the day of the wailing, they went mad and ran away. The servants of the family followed their tracks and searched for them.
They saw them sitting upright in the kiln, with a strange light on their bodies, shining like golden color.
The servants were frightened and approached them, but they did not speak. They were afraid and walked on foot.
Next, they peeked into a kiln and saw the seven masters, with the same appearance as before.
In this way, they went through all seven kilns, seeing them sitting upright and emitting light in each one.
Therefore, the people of Shaanxi revered them like gods and bowed to them in homage.

As a monk, he was crazy but not confused, foolish but wise, and no one could fathom his reasons.

He saw that the temple's construction of halls and pavilions was not yet complete - the princess of Yue had married Zheng Wanyun of Yingyang, although they harmonized like qin and se, they had no children for several years - Huai then went to the princess's house, and Wanyun burned incense, swept the floor, and waited for him.
The princess bowed and knelt, facing him, and Wanyun prayed to him, saying:
Since I was chosen as a consort, I wish to have a son to be my heir. Only you, Master, can bring this about?
Huai said:
It's easy!

Wanyun diligently listened as if hearing the Buddha's words, and took out the silk as requested and offered it.

I will have them born one after the other in the same year.
As predicted, at the beginning and end of the year, they were born accordingly.

The news spread like boiling water in the Wei River between the capital cities. Judging their status, it cannot be lightly discussed.

Biography of the Great Master Guangling of Xiaogang Temple in Yangzhou of the Tang Dynasty. The Great Master Guangling was a man from Weiyang. He did not mention his Dharma name. In the Huaihai area, they competed to call him the Great Master Guangling.

His physical appearance was quite ugly, and his nature was very cunning. His true and straightforward appearance was similar to that of butchers and fishermen, only his appearance as a monk was different.

He liked to drink alcohol and eat meat, and always wore thick silk fur - it can be known that it was heavy. Even in the heat of summer, he did not take it off for a moment, and lice and fleas gathered on it.
He lived in Xiaogang Temple, in a single room. Every evening, he closed the door and went to sleep, usually making it a habit.

Sometimes, when his crazy and rebellious nature arose, he would slaughter dogs and pigs. He would gather a few evil people to fight and beat others, or he would lie drunk on the side of the road. The people hated him for this.

In the Zhenyuan era, there was a young man who was known for his strength. Once, the young man was gambling with others when the Great Master became very angry and smashed the gambling table with his hand.
The young man laughed and said:
How dare a fool go against a strong man?
The Great Master scolded him and spat on his face. Then, he challenged the young man to fight. Thousands of onlookers surrounded them.
The young man was defeated by the Great Master and fled down the road.
Only then did people realize that he had spiritual powers.
He also often relied on his strength in crowded places, frequently entering the market to rob people of their money and silk. The people in the market all feared his bravery and dared not resist.
Later, an elderly monk called the Great Master and admonished him, saying:

Why don't you be more careful to keep the precepts? How can you eat alcohol and meat, slaughter dogs and pigs, forcibly snatch people's money and goods in the market, and fight with unruly young men? Your lack of discipline is extreme. How can this be the practice of a monk?
If one day you are not tolerated by the assembly and take your case to the officials, you will be dealt with according to the law. Where can you escape and hide?
Moreover, you deeply disgrace the Buddha's teachings.
The Great Master glared at him and said:
Flies and gnats merely buzz around putrid smells. How can you understand the aspirations of a great bird?
However, my Way is not something you can know.
Moreover, I am pure within and unstained without. How can I be the same as you, cramped and lacking in magnanimity?
The elder was unable to subdue him.

One day later, when he returned from outside and entered the room, someone peeked through a crack in the door - they saw the Great Master sitting on his seat emitting spiritual light, shining brightly from between his eyebrows, illuminating things clearly.

The onlookers were shocked and reported it. After a short while, the monks of the temple rushed to pay homage and praise him. Some repented for having slandered him before, while others snapped their fingers and sang praises.
The next day, the monks waited for the great master to come out and burn incense to pay respects.
When they opened the door, he was sitting in meditation with his eyes closed, already long gone.
From then on, people in Guangling copied his image and made offerings to him, calling him the Great Master.
The Biography of Mingzan of Nanyue in the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Mingzan of Nanyue in the Tang Dynasty. Shi Mingzan, unknown clan and birthplace.

In the beginning of the Tianbao era, he arrived at a temple on Nanyue, where he took on menial tasks, completely devoted to the temple, sleeping at night under a herd of cows, never weary.

Prime Minister Li Bi of Ye avoided the harm of Cui and Li, hid on Nanyue, and secretly observed what Chan did, saying:
He is an extraordinary person.
He listened to the chanting at midnight, the sound reverberating through the mountains and valleys.

At midnight, Li Gong secretly went to pay a visit. He bowed from afar at the door of the seat.

This is going to rob me.
Li Gong became even more respectful and just bowed.
Zan was just poking at the cow dung fire, taking out a yam to eat. After a while, he said:
You can sit on the ground.
He took half of the yam he was eating and gave it to Li Gong.

He said to Li Gong:
Be careful not to speak too much. Take this as ten years as prime minister.
Li Gong bowed and left.
After a month, the prefect offered sacrifice to the mountain and repaired the road extremely strictly.

Suddenly, in the middle of the night, there was a wind and thunder, and a peak collapsed, blocking the mountain path with a large rock. They then used several oxen to pull it and hundreds of people to shout and push it, but the force of the people and objects exhausted and the rock became more solid, with no other method.
Zhan said:
Why use so much trouble?
I will remove it at the beginning.
The crowd all laughed, and Zhan then stepped on the rock and moved it. Suddenly it turned and fell down, with a sound like thunder.
When the mountain path was opened, the monks bowed and leaped for joy. The entire prefecture called him a great sage, and the prefect treated him like a divine being.
Zhan quietly harbored the intention to leave.
Outside the temple, tigers and leopards suddenly formed a group, killing people every day, with no way to stop them.

The crowd said:
A large rock can still be pushed, but tigers and leopards should be easy to control.
So he gave him a staff, and they all followed behind to watch.
When they went out the door, they saw a tiger carrying him away.

At the end of the Tianbao era, Emperor Suzong of the Tang dynasty went on a northern tour and ascended the throne in Lingwu. He sent envoys to invite Hui.

The emperor was delighted and employed him, giving him power surpassing that of the chief minister, and he was in charge of the affairs of the Prince of Guangping's mansion.

You are my teacher and friend.
Now the three of us, father and sons, rely on your moral integrity.
Soon, Cui Yuan and Li Fugu harmed him because of his abilities. Hui was afraid and begged to travel to Hengyue. The emperor approved it.
He abstained from grains for several years and finally saw Zan.ğŸ”½Later, he ended up in the position of chief minister, just as Zan had predicted.

Tang Dynasty, Biography of Daijia of Cuyun Temple in Jianzhou, Biography of Daijia of Cuyun Temple in Jianzhou, Tang Dynasty, Huaiyi Shi Daijia, secular surname Wang, from Jinshui County.
